ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It's very helpful course if you want to learn light-matter interaction.

APHY 676 develops a framework to treat the dynamics of a wide variety of physical phenomena, particularly for interacting modes. There's a lot of classical mechanics, though probably not in a form you've seen too much before. I'd definitely recommend this course--it saved me a lot of time having to slog through textbooks and papers trying to learn this stuff on my own and helped me to understand nonlinear phenomena in a new light.

This is a fairly advanced course, which definitely requires a basic knowledge of optics, lagrangian mechanics and quantum mechanics. It is a great introduction to non-linear optics and quantum optics if these are the areas one wishes to pursue research in. If you are interested in seeing the transition between a purely classical approach, to a semiclassical approach, to a full quantum approach, and how close related they actually are, this is the course for you.
Yes, it is important to understand basic phenomenon of light-matter interaction. I would surely recommend it.

A great course for graduate student interested not only in learning about light matter interaction but also connections between classical and quantum mechanics.Also, doing the final project you can learn a lot.
I think it's a great course for optics/mesoscopic physics people. I would definitely recommend.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course gave me the tools to understand the physics of nonlinear optical processes and mathematically treat coupled-mode problems...the material covered will definitely prove useful in my research.
This opened up the way for me to start understanding non-linear phenomena and quantum optics, which is great for me, since that is exactly the fields I wish to do research in.

the course material is very good and it was nice to learn some of these things that are currently only explained in research papers. I didnt answer question 4b. My answer is the following: some classical physics topics were too slow and some mode dynamics and quantum things were too fast.
